compound.name: Logger
compound.brief: The "Logger" Class handles low power sleep for the main processor, interfacing with the real-time clock and modem, writing to the SD card, and passing data on to the data publishers.
compound.description:
A logger is a device that can control all functions of the modem sensors and that are attached to it and save the values of all variables measured by those sensors to an attached SD card. It must also work with a real-time clock to give timestamps to values. It may also work with a loggerModem for internet connection and send out data over the internet through one or more data publishers.

In this library, all loggers are Arduino-style small processor circuit boards.

Todo

Support half/quarter hour time zones

typeless_funcs.name: Logger
typeless_funcs.brief: Construct a new Logger object.

params.name: loggerID
params.description: A name for the logger - unless otherwise specified, files saved to the SD card will be named with the logger id and the date the file was started.

params.name: samplingFeatureUUID
params.description: The sampling feature UUID.

params.name: loggingIntervalMinutes
params.description: The frequency in minutes at which data should be logged

params.name: SDCardSSPin
params.description: The pin of the chip select/slave select for the SPI connection to the SD card

params.name: mcuWakePin
params.description: The pin used to wake the logger from deep sleep - expected to be attached to an alarm pin of the real-time clock. Use a value of -1 to prevent the board from sleeping.

params.name: inputArray
params.description: A pointer to a variableArray object instance providing data to be logged. This is NOT an array of variables, but an object of the variable array class.

groups.name: Basic Logging Parameters
groups.description: Public functions to get and set basic logging parameters

members.name: _loggerID
members.brief: The logger id.

members.name: _loggingIntervalMinutes
members.brief: The logging interval in minutes.

members.name: _remainingShortIntervals
members.brief: The initial number of samples to log at an interval of 1 minute for fast field verification.

members.name: _SDCardSSPin
members.brief: Digital pin number on the mcu controlling the SD card slave select.

members.name: _SDCardPowerPin
members.brief: Digital pin number on the mcu controlling SD card power.

members.name: _mcuWakePin
members.brief: Digital pin number on the mcu receiving interrupts to wake from deep-sleep.

members.name: _wakePinMode
members.brief: The pin mode used for wake up on the clock alert pin.
members.description: Must be either INPUT OR INPUT_PULLUP with an AVR board. On a SAM/D board INPUT_PULLDOWN is also an option. Optional with a default value of INPUT_PULLUP. The DS3231 has an active low interrupt, so the pull-up resistors should be enabled.

members.name: _ledPin
members.brief: Digital pin number on the mcu used to output an alert that the logger is measuring.
members.description: Expected to be connected to a LED.

members.name: _buttonPin
members.brief: Digital pin number on the mcu receiving interrupts to enter testing mode.
members.description: Expected to be connected to a user button.

members.name: _buttonPinMode
members.brief: The pin mode used for interrupts on the testing (button) pin.
members.description: Must be either INPUT OR INPUT_PULLUP with an AVR board. On a SAM/D board INPUT_PULLDOWN is also an option. Optional with a default value of INPUT_PULLUP.

members.name: _samplingFeatureUUID
members.brief: The sampling feature UUID.

members.name: setLoggerID
members.brief: Set the Logger ID.
members.description: Unless otherwise specified, files saved to the SD card will be named with the logger id and the date the file was started.

params.name: loggerID
params.description: A pointer to the logger ID

members.name: getLoggerID
members.brief: Get the Logger ID.
members.return_value: A pointer to the logger ID

members.name: setLoggingInterval
members.brief: Set the logging interval in minutes.

params.name: loggingIntervalMinutes
params.description: The frequency with which to update sensor values and write data to the SD card.

members.name: getLoggingInterval
members.brief: Get the Logging Interval.
members.return_value: The logging interval in minutes

members.name: setinitialShortIntervals
members.brief: Set the number of initial datapoints to log (and publish) at 1-minute intervals before beginning logging on the regular logging interval.

params.name: initialShortIntervals
params.description: The number of 1-minute intervals. This number of transmissions will be performed with an interval of 1 minute regardless of the programmed interval. Useful for fast field verification.

members.name: getinitialShortIntervals
members.brief: Get the number of 1-minute intervals at the start before logging on the regular logging interval.
members.return_value: The number of 1-minute intervals at the start before logging on the regular logging interval

members.name: setSamplingFeatureUUID
members.brief: Set the universally unique identifier (UUID or GUID) of the sampling feature.

params.name: samplingFeatureUUID
params.description: A pointer to the sampling feature UUID

members.name: getSamplingFeatureUUID
members.brief: Get the Sampling Feature UUID.
members.return_value: The sampling feature UUID

members.name: setSDCardPwr
members.brief: Set a digital pin number (on the mcu) to use to control power to the SD card and activate it as an output pin.
members.description:
Because this sets the pin mode, this function should only be called during the setup() or loop() portion of an Arduino program.

Warning

This functionality is not tested!

params.name: SDCardPowerPin
params.description: A digital pin number on the mcu controlling power to the SD card.

members.name: turnOnSDcard
members.brief: Send power to the SD card by setting the SDCardPowerPin HIGH.
members.description: Optionally waits for the card to "settle." Has no effect if a pin has not been set to control power to the SD card.

params.name: waitToSettle
params.description: True to add a short (6ms) delay between powering on the card and beginning initialization. Defaults to true.

members.name: turnOffSDcard
members.brief: Cut power to the SD card by setting the SDCardPowerPin LOW.
members.description: Optionally waits for the card to do "housekeeping" before cutting the power. Has o effect if a pin has not been set to control power to the SD card.

params.name: waitForHousekeeping
params.description: True to add a 1 second delay between to allow any on-chip writing to complete before cutting power. Defaults to true.

members.name: setSDCardSS
members.brief: Set a digital pin number for the slave select (chip select) of the SD card and activate it as an output pin.
members.description:
This over-writes the value (if any) given in the constructor. The pin mode of this pin will be set as OUTPUT.

Because this sets the pin mode, this function should only be called during the setup() or loop() portion of an Arduino program.

params.name: SDCardSSPin
params.description: The pin on the mcu connected to the slave select of the SD card.

members.name: setSDCardPins
members.brief: Set both pin numbers related to the SD card and activate them as output pins.
members.description:
These over-write the values (if any) given in the constructor. The pin mode of these pins will be set as OUTPUT.

Because this sets the pin mode, this function should only be called during the setup() or loop() portion of an Arduino program.

params.name: SDCardSSPin
params.description: The pin on the mcu connected to the slave select of the SD card.

params.name: SDCardPowerPin
params.description: A digital pin number on the mcu controlling power to the SD card.

members.name: setRTCWakePin
members.brief: Set digital pin number for the wake up pin used as an RTC interrupt and activate it in the given pin mode.
members.description:
This over-writes the value (if any) given in the constructor. Use a value of -1 to prevent the board from attempting to sleep. If using a SAMD board with the internal RTC, the value of the pin is irrelevant as long as it is positive.

Because this sets the pin mode, this function should only be called during the setup() or loop() portion of an Arduino program.

Note

This sets the pin mode but does NOT enable the interrupt! The interrupt is enabled with Logger::enableLoggerInterrupts(), called internally during Logger::begin().

params.name: mcuWakePin
params.description: The pin on the mcu to be used to wake the mcu from deep sleep.

params.name: wakePinMode
params.description: The pin mode to be used for wake up on the clock alert pin. Must be either INPUT OR INPUT_PULLUP. Optional with a default value of INPUT_PULLUP. The DS3231 has an active low interrupt, so the pull-up resistors should be enabled.

members.name: setAlertPin
members.brief: Set the digital pin number to put out an alert that a measurement is being logged and activate it as an output pin.
members.description:
The pin mode of this pin will be set as OUTPUT. This is intended to be a pin with a LED on it so you can see the light come on when a measurement is being taken.

Because this sets the pin mode, this function should only be called during the setup() or loop() portion of an Arduino program.

params.name: ledPin
params.description: The pin on the mcu to be held HIGH while sensor data is being collected and logged.

members.name: alertOn
members.brief: Set the alert pin high.

members.name: alertOff
members.brief: Set the alert pin low.

members.name: setTestingModePin
members.brief: Set the digital pin number for an interrupt pin used to enter testing mode, activate that pin as the given input type, and attach the testing interrupt to it.
members.description:
Intended to be used for a pin attached to a button or other manual interrupt source.

Because this sets the pin mode, this function should only be called during the setup() or loop() portion of an Arduino program.

Once in testing mode, the logger will attempt to connect the the internet and take 25 measurements spaced at 5 second intervals writing the results to the main output destination (ie, Serial). Testing mode cannot be entered while the logger is taking a scheduled measurement. No data is written to the SD card in testing mode.

Note

This sets the pin mode but does NOT enable the interrupt! The interrupt is enabled with Logger::enableLoggerInterrupts(), called internally during Logger::begin().

params.name: buttonPin
params.description: The pin on the mcu to listen to for a value-change interrupt.

params.name: buttonPinMode
params.description: The pin mode to be used for the button pin. Must be either INPUT OR INPUT_PULLUP. Optional with a default value of INPUT. Using INPUT_PULLUP will enable processor input resistors, while using INPUT will explicitly disable them. If your pin is externally pulled down or the button is a normally open (NO) switch with common (COM) connected to Vcc, like the EnviroDIY Mayfly), you should use the INPUT pin mode. Conversely, if your button connect to ground when activated, you should enable the processor pull-up resistors using INPUT_PULLUP.

members.name: setLoggerPins
members.brief: Set the digital pin numbers and activate pin modes for the five pins of interest for the logger.
members.description: Because this sets the pin mode, this function should only be called during the setup() or loop() portion of an Arduino program.

params.name: mcuWakePin
params.description: The pin on the mcu to listen to for a value-change interrupt to wake from deep sleep. The mode of this pin will be set to wakePinMode.

params.name: SDCardSSPin
params.description: The pin on the mcu connected to the slave select of the SD card. The pin mode of this pin will be set as OUTPUT.

params.name: SDCardPowerPin
params.description: A digital pin number on the mcu controlling power to the SD card. The pin mode of this pin will be set as OUTPUT.

params.name: buttonPin
params.description: The pin on the mcu to listen to for a value-change interrupt to enter testing mode. The mode of this pin will be set to buttonPinMode.

params.name: ledPin
params.description: The pin on the mcu to be held HIGH while sensor data is being collected and logged. The pin mode of this pin will be set as OUTPUT.

params.name: wakePinMode
params.description: The pin mode to be used for wake up on the mcuWakePin (clock alert) pin. Must be either INPUT OR INPUT_PULLUP. Optional with a default value of INPUT_PULLUP. The DS3231 has an active low interrupt, so the pull-up resistors should be enabled.

params.name: buttonPinMode
params.description: The pin mode to be used for the button pin. Must be either INPUT OR INPUT_PULLUP. Optional with a default value of INPUT. Using INPUT_PULLUP will enable processor input resistors, while using INPUT will explicitly disable them. If your pin is externally pulled down or the button is a normally open (NO) switch with common (COM) connected to Vcc, like the EnviroDIY Mayfly), you should use the INPUT pin mode. Conversely, if your button is active when connected to ground, you should enable the processor pull-up resistors using INPUT_PULLUP.

members.name: enableRTCPinISR
members.brief: Attaches the RTC ISR to the wake pin.
members.description:
Warning

The RTC ISR CANNOT be attached to the wake pin before the RTC is begun! Initializing/resetting the RTC can trigger an interrupt on the wake pin. That triggered interrupt will attempt to change the RTC's interrupt flag before the RTC is fully initialized, causing a crash or confused behavior. This function is protected to protect users from calling it in the wrong order.

Note

This function is excluded when using the built in RTC on the SAMD21 (ie #define MS_USE_RTC_ZERO) because there is no pin involved

members.name: enableTestingISR
members.brief: Attaches the testing ISR to the button pin.
members.description:
Warning

The testing ISR shouldn't be attached before the sensors have been begun. Doing so may cause strange results. This function is protected to protect users from calling it in the wrong order.

Note

The testing ISR itself only wakes the board and sets a flag. The flag is then checked and acted on in the checkInterval / checkMarkedInterval functions and the logData / logDataAndPublish functions.

groups.name: Attached Variable Array Functions
groups.description: Public functions to get information about the attached variable array

members.name: _internalArray
members.brief: A pointer to the internal variable array instance.

members.name: setVariableArray
members.brief: Set the variable array object.

params.name: inputArray
params.description: A pointer to a variable array object instance. This is NOT an array of variables, but an object of the variable array class.

members.name: getArrayVarCount
members.brief: Get the number of variables in the internal variable array object.
members.return_value: The number of variables in the internal variable array object

members.name: getParentSensorNameAtI
members.brief: Get the name of the parent sensor of the variable at the given position in the internal variable array object.
members.return_value: The name of the parent sensor of that variable, if applicable.

params.name: position_i
params.description: The position of the variable in the array.

members.name: getParentSensorNameAndLocationAtI
members.brief: Get the name and pin location of the parent sensor of the variable at the given position in the internal variable array object.
members.return_value: The concatenated name and pin location of the parent sensor of that variable, if applicable.

params.name: position_i
params.description: The position of the variable in the array.

members.name: getVarNameAtI
members.brief: Get the name of the variable at the given position in the internal variable array object.
members.description: Variable names must follow the controlled vocabulary documented here: http://vocabulary.odm2.org/variablename/
members.return_value: The variable name

params.name: position_i
params.description: The position of the variable in the array.

members.name: getVarUnitAtI
members.brief: Get the unit of the variable at the given position in the internal variable array object.
members.description: Variable units must follow the controlled vocabulary documented here: http://vocabulary.odm2.org/units/
members.return_value: The variable unit

params.name: position_i
params.description: The position of the variable in the array.

members.name: getVarCodeAtI
members.brief: Get the customized code of the variable at the given position in the internal variable array object.
members.return_value: The variable code

params.name: position_i
params.description: The position of the variable in the array.

members.name: getVarUUIDAtI
members.brief: Get the UUID of the variable at the given position in the internal variable array object.
members.return_value: The variable UUID

params.name: position_i
params.description: The position of the variable in the array.

members.name: getVarUUIDStringAtI
members.brief: Get the UUID of the variable at the given position in the internal variable array object.
members.return_value: The variable UUID

params.name: position_i
params.description: The position of the variable in the array.

members.name: getVarResolutionAtI
members.brief: Get the resolution (number of decimal places) of the variable at the given position in the internal variable array object.
members.return_value: The variable resolution

params.name: position_i
params.description: The position of the variable in the array.

members.name: getValueAtI
members.brief: Get the most recent value of the variable at the given position in the internal variable array object.
members.description:
Note

This does not trigger a new reading from the sensor for sensor reported variables or a new call of the calculation function for calculated variables.
members.return_value: The value of the variable as a float.

params.name: position_i
params.description: The position of the variable in the array.

members.name: getValueStringAtI
members.brief: Get the most recent value of the variable at the given position in the internal variable array object.
members.description:
Note

This does not trigger a new reading from the sensor for sensor reported variables or a new call of the calculation function for calculated variables.
members.return_value: The value of the variable as a string with the correct number of significant figures.

params.name: position_i
params.description: The position of the variable in the array.

members.name: formatValueStringAtI
members.brief: Get the string representing a particular value of the variable at the given position in the internal variable array object.
members.return_value: The given value as a string with the correct number of significant figures.

params.name: position_i
params.description: The position of the variable in the array.

params.name: value
params.description: The value to format.

groups.name: Internet and Publisher Functions
groups.description: Public functions for internet and dataPublishers

members.name: _logModem
members.brief: The internal modem instance.
members.description:
Note

The internal _logModem must be a POINTER not a reference because it is possible for no modem to be attached (and thus the pointer could be null). It is not possible to have a null reference.

members.name: dataPublishers
members.brief: An array of all of the attached data publishers.

members.name: attachModem
members.brief: Attach a loggerModem to the logger to provide internet access.
members.description: See Modem and Internet Functions for more information on how the modem must be set up before it is attached to the logger. You must include an ampersand to tie in the already created modem! If you do not attach a modem, no action will be taken to publish data.

params.name: modem
params.description: An instance of the loggerModem class

members.name: syncRTC
members.brief: Use the attached loggerModem to synchronize the real-time clock with NIST time servers.
members.return_value: True if clock synchronization was successful

members.name: registerDataPublisher
members.brief: Register a data publisher object to receive data from the logger.
members.return_value: A pointer to the underlying logger's loggerModem to use for chaining

params.name: publisher
params.description: A dataPublisher object

members.name: checkRemotesConnectionNeeded
members.brief: Check if any data publishers need an Internet connection for the next publish call.
members.return_value: True if any remotes need a connection.

members.name: publishDataToRemotes
members.brief: Publish data to all registered data publishers.

params.name: forceFlush
params.description: Ask the publishers to flush buffered data immediately.

members.name: sendDataToRemotes
members.brief: Retained for backwards compatibility, use publishDataToRemotes() in new code.
members.description: Deprecated in v0.22.5

members.name: publishMetadataToRemotes
members.brief: Publish metadata to all registered data publishers.
members.description:
This should only be called at startup.

See also

dataPublisherBase::publishMetadata()

groups.name: SD Cards and Saving Data
groups.description: Public functions for logging data to an SD card

members.name: sd
members.brief: An internal reference to SdFat for SD card control.

members.name: logFile
members.brief: An internal reference to an SdFat file instance.

members.name: _fileName
members.brief: An internal reference to the current filename.

members.name: setFileName
members.brief: Set the file name, if you want to decide on it in advance.
members.description: If the file name is set using this function, the same file name will be used for every single file created by the logger.

params.name: fileName
params.description: The file name

members.name: setFileName
members.brief: Set the file name, if you want to decide on it in advance.
members.description: If the file name is set using this function, the same file name will be used for every single file created by the logger.

params.name: fileName
params.description: The file name

members.name: getFileName
members.brief: Get the current filename.
members.description: This may be a single filename set using the setFileName(name) function or an auto-generated filename which is a concatenation of the logger id and the date when the file was started.
members.return_value: The name of the file data is currently being saved to.

members.name: printFileHeader
members.brief: Print a header out to a stream.
members.description: This removes need to pass around very long string objects which can crash the logger

params.name: stream
params.description: An Arduino stream instance - expected to be an SdFat file - but could also be the "main" Serial port for debugging.

members.name: printSensorDataCSV
members.brief: Print a comma separated list of values of sensor data - including the time in the logging timezone - out over an Arduino stream.

params.name: stream
params.description: An Arduino stream instance - expected to be an SdFat file - but could also be the "main" Serial port for debugging.

members.name: initializeSDCard
members.brief: Check if the SD card is available and ready to write to.
members.description: We run this check before every communication with the SD card to prevent hanging.
members.return_value: True if the SD card is ready

members.name: createLogFile
members.brief: Create a file on the SD card and set the created, modified, and accessed timestamps in that file.
members.description: The filename will be the value specified in the function. If desired, a header will also be written to the file based on the variable information from the variable array. This can be used to force a logger to create a file with a secondary file name.
members.return_value: True if the file was successfully created.

params.name: filename
params.description: The name of the file to create

params.name: writeDefaultHeader
params.description: True to write a header to the file, default is false

members.name: createLogFile
members.brief: Create a file on the SD card and set the created, modified, and accessed timestamps in that file.
members.description: The filename will be the one set by setFileName(String) or generated using the logger id and the date. If desired, a header will also be written to the file based on the variable information from the variable array.
members.return_value: True if the file was successfully created.

params.name: writeDefaultHeader
params.description: True to write a header to the file, default is false

members.name: logToSD
members.brief: Open a file with the given name on the SD card and append the given line to the bottom of it.
members.description: If a file with the specified name does not already exist, attempt to create the file and add a header to it. Set the modified and accessed timestamps of the file to the current time.
members.return_value: True if the file was successfully accessed or created and data appended to it.

params.name: filename
params.description: The name of the file to write to

params.name: rec
params.description: The line to be written to the file

members.name: logToSD
members.brief: Open a file named with the current internal filename value and append the given line to the bottom of it.
members.description: If a file with the with the internal filename does not already exist, attempt to create a file with that name and add a header to it. Set the modified and accessed timestamps of the file to the current time.
members.return_value: True if the file was successfully accessed or created and data appended to it.

params.name: rec
params.description: The line to be written to the file

members.name: logToSD
members.brief: Open a file named with the current internal filename value and append a line to the bottom of it with the most recent values of all variables in the variable array as a comma separated list.
members.description: If a file with the with the internal filename does not already exist, attempt to create the file and add a header to it. Set the modified and accessed timestamps of the file to the current time.
members.return_value: True if the file was successfully accessed or created and data appended to it.

members.name: generateFileName
members.brief: Generate a file name with the current date and time appended to it.
members.description:
Note

This cannot be called until after the RTC is started
members.return_value: The generated file name

params.name: include_time
params.description: True to include the time in the filename

params.name: extension
params.description: The file extension to use

params.name: filePrefix
params.description: The prefix to use for the file name, optional, with an default value of nullptr. If not provided, the logger ID will be used.

members.name: generateAutoFileName
members.brief: Generate a file name from the logger id and the current date.
members.description:
Note

This cannot be called until after the RTC is started

members.name: setFileTimestamp
members.brief: Set a timestamp on a file.

params.name: fileToStamp
params.description: The filename to change the timestamp of

params.name: stampFlag
params.description: The "flag" of the timestamp to change - should be T_CREATE, T_WRITE, or T_ACCESS

members.name: openFile
members.brief: Open or creates a file, converting a string file name to a character file name.
members.return_value: True if a file was successfully opened or created.

params.name: filename
params.description: The name of the file to open

params.name: createFile
params.description: True to create the file if it did not already exist

params.name: writeDefaultHeader
params.description: True to add a header to the file if it is created

members.name: fileDateTimeCallback
members.brief: This function is used to automatically mark files as created/accessed/modified when operations are done by the SdFat library.
members.description: This function will be called automatically by SdFat, but is not intended to be used at any other time.

params.name: date
params.description: Pointer to a uint16_t to store the date

params.name: time
params.description: Pointer to a uint16_t to store the time

groups.name: Clock and Timezones
groups.description: Public functions to access the clock in proper format and time zone

members.name: _loggerUTCOffset
members.brief: The static timezone data is being logged in.
members.description:
Note

All logger objects, if multiple are used, will be in the same timezone.

members.name: _loggerEpoch
members.brief: The start of the epoch for the logger.
members.description:
Note

This is fixed as MS_LOGGER_EPOCH

members.name: _loggerRTCOffset
members.brief: The static difference between the timezone of the RTC and the timezone data is being logged in.
members.description:
Note

All logger objects, if multiple are used, will be will have the same offset.

members.name: setRTClock
members.brief:
Pass-through to loggerClock::setRTClock(time_t
UTCEpochSeconds,0, epochStart::unix_epoch) Verify that the input value is sane and if so set the real time clock to the given time.
members.description:
Deprecated in v0.37.0

Call loggerClock::setRTClock(time_t ts, int8_t utcOffset , epochStart epoch) directly in new programs.
members.return_value: True if the input timestamp passes sanity checks and the clock has been successfully set.

params.name: UTCEpochSeconds
params.description: The number of seconds since 1970 in UTC.

members.name: checkInterval
members.brief: Check if the CURRENT time is an even interval of the logging rate.
members.return_value: True if the current time on the RTC is an even interval of the logging rate.

members.name: checkMarkedInterval
members.brief: Check if the MARKED time is an even interval of the logging rate - That is the value saved in the static variable markedLocalUnixTime.
members.description: This should be used in conjunction with markTime() to ensure that all data outputs from a single data update session (SD, EnviroDIY, serial printing, etc) have the same timestamp even though the update routine may take several (or many) seconds.
members.return_value: True if the marked time is an even interval of the logging rate.

members.name: setLoggerTimeZone
members.brief: Set the static timezone that the data will be logged in.
members.description:
Note

This must be set.

params.name: timeZone
params.description: The timezone data should be saved to the SD card in. This need not be the same as the timezone of the real time clock.

members.name: getLoggerTimeZone
members.brief: Get the Logger Time Zone.
members.return_value: The timezone data is be saved to the SD card in. This is not be the same as the timezone of the real time clock.

members.name: setRTCTimeZone
members.brief: A passthrough to loggerClock::setRTCOffset(int8_t offsetHours); set the static timezone that the RTC is programmed in.
members.description:
Deprecated in v0.37.0

Use loggerClock::setRTCOffset(_offsetHours) in new code!

Note

I VERY, VERY STRONGLY RECOMMEND SETTING THE RTC IN UTC

params.name: timeZone
params.description: The offset of the real-time clock (RTC) from UTC in hours

members.name: getRTCTimeZone
members.brief: A passthrough to loggerClock::getRTCOffset(); get the timezone of the real-time clock (RTC).
members.description:
Deprecated in v0.37.0

Use loggerClock::getRTCOffset() in new code!
members.return_value: The offset of the real-time clock (RTC) from UTC in hours

members.name: setTZOffset
members.brief: Set the offset between the built-in clock and the time zone where the data is being recorded.
members.description: If your RTC is set in UTC and your logging timezone is EST, this should be -5. If your RTC is set in EST and your timezone is EST this does not need to be called.

params.name: offset
params.description: The difference between the timezone of the RTC and the saved data

members.name: getTZOffset
members.brief: Get the offset between the built-in clock and the time zone where the data is being recorded.
members.return_value: The offset between the built-in clock and the time zone where the data is being recorded.

members.name: getNowLocalEpoch
members.brief: Get the current epoch time from the RTC and correct it to the logging time zone.
members.return_value: The number of seconds from the start of the UNIX epoch in the logging time zone.

members.name: getNowParts
members.brief: Get the current epoch time from the RTC and return it as individual parts.
members.description:
Remark

Unlike the near-identical loggerClock::getNowAsParts(), this function converts all of the parts to the loggers timezone and writes the logger timezone to the tz_offset variable.

params.name: seconds
params.description: [out] Reference to a variable where the seconds will be stored

params.name: minutes
params.description: [out] Reference to a variable where the minutes will be stored

params.name: hours
params.description: [out] Reference to a variable where the hours will be stored

params.name: day
params.description: [out] Reference to a variable where the day will be stored

params.name: month
params.description: [out] Reference to a variable where the month will be stored

params.name: year
params.description: [out] Reference to a variable where the year will be stored

params.name: tz_offset
params.description: [out] Reference to a variable where the timezone offset will be stored

members.name: getNowUTCEpoch
members.brief: Get the current Universal Coordinated Time (UTC) epoch time from the RTC.
members.return_value: The number of seconds from the start of the UNIX epoch.

members.name: formatDateTime_ISO8601
members.brief: Convert an epoch time into a ISO8601 formatted string.
members.description: This assumes the supplied date/time is in the LOGGER's timezone and the LOGGER's epoch start. It adds the LOGGER's offset as the time zone offset in the string.
members.return_value: An ISO8601 formatted String.

params.name: epochSeconds
params.description: The number of seconds since the start of the logger's epoch (MS_LOGGER_EPOCH).

members.name: formatDateTime
members.brief: Convert an epoch time into a character string based on the input strftime format string and put it into the given buffer.
members.description:
This assumes the supplied date/time is in the LOGGER's timezone and adds the LOGGER's offset as the time zone offset in the string.

See also

https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/chrono/c/strftime for possible formatting strings.

Note

This function DOES NOTE SUPPORT TIMEZONES. Do not use the z or Z inputs!

params.name: buffer
params.description: A buffer to put the finished string into. Make sure that the buffer is big enough to hold all of the characters!

params.name: fmt
params.description: The strftime format string.

params.name: epochSeconds
params.description: The number of seconds since the start of the given epoch in the given offset from UTC.

members.name: isRTCSane
members.brief: Passthrough to loggerClock::isRTCSane(); check that the current time on the RTC is within a "sane" range.
members.description:
Deprecated in v0.37.0

Use loggerClock::isRTCSane() directly in new code!

To be sane the clock must be between EARLIEST_SANE_UNIX_TIMESTAMP and LATEST_SANE_UNIX_TIMESTAMP.
members.return_value: True if the current time on the RTC passes sanity range checking

members.name: markTime
members.brief: Set static variables for the date/time.
members.description: This is needed so that all data outputs (SD, EnviroDIY, serial printing, etc) print the same time for updating the sensors - even though the routines to update the sensors and to output the data may take several seconds. It is not currently possible to output the instantaneous time an individual sensor was updated, just a single marked time. By custom, this should be called before updating the sensors, not after.

groups.name: Do-It-All Convience Functions
groups.description: Convience functions to call several of the above functions

members.name: markedLocalUnixTime
members.brief: The static "marked" epoch time for the local timezone.

members.name: markedUTCUnixTime
members.brief: The static "marked" epoch time for UTC.

members.name: isLoggingNow
members.brief: Internal flag set to true when logger is currently updating sensors or writing to the SD card.

members.name: isTestingNow
members.brief: Internal flag set to true when the logger is going through the "testing mode" routine.

members.name: startTesting
members.brief: Internal flag set to true when the logger should begin the "testing mode" routine when it finishes other operations.

members.name: begin
members.brief: Set all pin levels and does initial communication with the real-time clock and SD card to prepare the logger for full functionality.
members.description:
This is used for operations that cannot happen in the logger constructor

  • they must happen at run time, not at compile time.

params.name: loggerID
params.description: An ID for the logger - will be used to auto-generate file names. Supplying a logger ID here will override any value given in the constructor.

params.name: loggingIntervalMinutes
params.description: The interval in minutes at which to log data. Supplying an interval here will override any value given in the constructor.

params.name: inputArray
params.description: A variableArray object instance providing data to be logged. This is NOT an array of variables, but an object of the variable array class. Supplying a variableArray object here will override any value given in the constructor.

members.name: begin
members.brief: Set all pin levels and does initial communication with the real-time clock and SD card to prepare the logger for full functionality.
members.description:
This is used for operations that cannot happen in the logger constructor

  • they must happen at run time, not at compile time.

params.name: inputArray
params.description: A variableArray object instance providing data to be logged. This is NOT an array of variables, but an object of the variable array class. Supplying a variableArray object here will override any value given in the constructor.

members.name: begin
members.brief: Set all pin levels and does initial communication with the real-time clock and SD card to prepare the logger for full functionality.
members.description:
This is used for operations that cannot happen in the logger constructor

  • they must happen at run time, not at compile time.

members.name: logData
members.brief: This is a one-and-done to log data.
members.description:
Note

If sleepBeforeReturning is set to false, the logger WILL NOT sleep between readings.

params.name: sleepBeforeReturning
params.description: True to put the logger to sleep before returning from the function; optional with a default value of true.

members.name: logDataAndPublish
members.brief: This is a one-and-done to log data and publish the results to any associated publishers.
members.description:
Note

If sleepBeforeReturning is set to false, the logger WILL NOT sleep between readings.

params.name: sleepBeforeReturning
params.description: True to put the logger to sleep before returning from the function; optional with a default value of true.

members.name: makeInitialConnections
members.brief: Wakes and sets up the modem, connects to the internet, syncs the RTC with NIST, and publishes metadata for all attached publishers.
members.description: This is only to be run at startup. It should be run after beginning the logger and attaching the modem and sensors.

groups.name: Sleep and Power Saving
groups.description:
Public Functions for sleeping the logger

AVR Sleep modes

In the avr/sleep.h file, the call names of these 5 sleep modes are: SLEEP_MODE_IDLE - the least power savings SLEEP_MODE_ADC SLEEP_MODE_PWR_SAVE SLEEP_MODE_STANDBY SLEEP_MODE_PWR_DOWN - the most power savings

SAMD21 Sleep Modes

The SAM D21/DA1 have two software-selectable sleep modes, Idle and Stand-by. In Idle mode, the CPU is stopped while all other functions can be kept running. In Stand-by mode, all clocks and functions are stopped, expect those selected to continue running. The device supports SleepWalking. This feature allows the peripheral to wake up from sleep based on predefined conditions, and thus allows the CPU to wake up only when needed, e.g., when a threshold is crossed or a result is ready. The Event System supports synchronous and asynchronous events, allowing peripherals to receive, react to and send events even in Stand-by mode.

SAMD51 Sleep Modes

The device can be set in a sleep mode. In sleep mode, the CPU is stopped and the peripherals are either active or idle, according to the sleep mode depth:

  • Idle sleep mode:
    • The CPU is stopped.
    • Synchronous clocks are stopped except when requested.
    • The logic is retained.
  • Standby sleep mode:
    • The CPU is stopped as well as the peripherals.
    • The logic is retained, and power domain gating can be used to fully or partially turn off the PDSYSRAM power domain.
  • Hibernate sleep mode:
    • PDCORESW power domain is turned OFF.
    • The backup power domain is kept powered to allow few features to run (RTC, 32KHz clock sources, and wake-up from external pins).
    • The PDSYSRAM power domain can be retained according to software configuration.
  • Backup sleep mode:
    • Only the backup domain is kept powered to allow few features to run (RTC, 32KHz clock sources, and wake-up from external pins).
    • The PDBKUPRAM power domain can be retained according to software configuration.
  • Off sleep mode:
    • The entire device is powered off.
Bit Settings
ValueNameDefinition
0x0Reserved-
0x1Reserved-
0x2IDLECPU, AHBx, and APBx clocks are OFF
0x3ReservedReserved
0x4STANDBYAll Clocks are OFF
0x5HIBERNATEBackup domain is ON as well as some PDRAMs
0x6BACKUPOnly Backup domain is powered ON
0x7OFFAll power domains are powered OFF

Note

For the SAMD51, hibernate, backup, and off modes cause a full system reset on wake. Because we don't want to fully reset the device (and go back to the setup) on wake, the lowest power mode we can use is standby.

members.name: systemSleep
members.brief: Put the mcu to sleep to conserve battery life and handle post-interrupt wake actions.
members.description:
Note

This DOES NOT sleep or wake the sensors!!

Warning

During sleep, the I2C/Wire interface is disabled and the SCL and SDA pins are forced low to save power. Any attempt to communicate with an I2C device during sleep (ie, thorough an interrupt) will cause the board to hang indefinitely.

members.name: wakeISR
members.brief: Set up the Interrupt Service Request for waking.
members.description:
In this case, we're doing nothing, we just want the processor to wake. This must be a static function (which means it can only call other static functions.)

Deprecated in v0.37.0

Use loggerClock::rtcISR() in new code!

groups.name: Sensor Testing Mode
groups.description: Public functions for a "sensor testing" mode

members.name: benchTestingMode
members.brief: Execute bench testing mode if enabled.
members.description:
Note

Does nothing unless MS_LOGGERBASE_BUTTON_BENCH_TEST is defined true in either the configuration file or a build flag.

In testing mode, the logger uses the loggerModem, if attached, to connect to the internet. It then powers up all sensors tied to variable in the internal variable array. The logger then updates readings from all sensors 25 times with a 5 second wait in between. All results are output to the "main" output - ie Serial - and NOT to the SD card. After 25 measurements, the sensors are put to sleep, the modem is disconnected from the internet, and the logger goes back to sleep.

params.name: sleepBeforeReturning
params.description: True to put the logger to sleep before returning from the function; optional with a default value of true.

members.name: testingISR
members.brief: The interrupt service routine called when an interrupt is detected on the pin assigned for "testing" mode.
